body: EVEN with the gaudy architect models, nobody really knows what the proposed $1.4 billion retractable-roof West Side football stadium in Manhattan, the one that would be constructed on a platform above the railyard between 30th and 34th Streets near the Hudson River, would look like. But just about everybody has an opinion about it. The Jets, the
title: Sports of The Times; Tailgaters To Jets: Stay or Go To Shea

body: In 1652, when the Dutch West India Company bought a tract of wilderness next to the water in southwest Brooklyn, settlers called the area Yellow Hook, for the color of the clay under their feet. Two hundred and one years later, in the aftermath of a regional yellow fever epidemic, the people living in the area reconsidered. Following a pattern that
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; A Boxful Of the Present To Open When It's The Past

In a German hotel room bugged by American agents, a Yemeni sheik was murmuring about jihad, a federal agent was posing as a former Black Panther eager to give millions to terrorists, and a roundish Yemeni man with a checkered past was egging on the others in his
title: Terror Case Hinges on a Wobbly Key Player

body: The killing of the Connecticut college student stumped detectives from the moment his body was found wrapped in a blanket and dumped on a road of stately Brooklyn homes 13 months ago. The early weeks of the investigation only brought new questions: Were the classmates he was with that night involved? Had he left a house party alone, meeting a
title: Brooklyn Teenager Arrested in 2003 Murder of College Student

body: It is nearly 3 a.m., and traffic on the Bayonne Bridge is so light that this link between New Jersey and Staten Island looks almost like some rural river crossing. Yet from down beneath the graceful steel-arch span, in a spot illuminated by the moonlight, comes an angry roar, followed by a tremendous rumble. The Beast of the Kill Van Kull is out
title: Beneath The Harbor, It's Dig or Else; Dredging Project Makes Way For Newer, Larger Ships

body: Of the several cafes along Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, where Arab immigrants and Arab-Americans gather, the Arabesque Cafe and Bazaar draws a consistently younger crowd of card-players and argileh (hookah) smokers. title: THE NEXT WAVE: SCENES; Wafting in the Cafe, Smoke of an Argileh, (It's Hookah to You)

body: One bartender shot and killed another at a tavern in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said. The victim, James Trippett, 34, who worked at the BR Stars tavern, was shot four times in the torso and was pronounced dead at Victory Memorial Hospital, the police said. The police arrested James Pallonetti, 45, who was also identified as a bartender at
title: Bartender Is Fatally Shot

body: ON Saturday afternoon, Nov. 6, a day before tens of thousands of runners and spectators descended on Central Park for the New York City Marathon, a group of young men on steel-framed, fat-tired bicycles had a corner of the park all to themselves. They were perched atop a jagged gray outcrop overlooking the bridle path. To geologists the ancient
title: The Evel Knievels of Central Park

body: It was a plan that looked forward in part by looking back. In August 2000, New York City announced that it had taken a long unused freightyard on the Brooklyn waterfront, cleared out the weeds, replaced rusted old equipment and prepared the 33 acres to be an active yard. City officials said that freight could once more be transferred from railroad
title: City Still Hopes To Bring Life To Railyard And Barge Link

body: With his spiky blond hair and Pokémon T-shirt, Vadim Khomenko looks like a typical 9-year-old. title: The Neediest Cases; Comforting Children Who've Had a Devastating Loss

body: A woman was shot fatally yesterday morning in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn during an argument in what appeared to be a gambling and after-hours club, the police and witnesses said. title: Woman Is Killed by Gunfire at a Brooklyn Club

body: FOR a New Yorker just one day shy of turning 100 years old, the subway kept crazy hours yesterday. In other words, there were no hours it did not keep. As its neighbors around the world locked up their stations and turned out their lights, the subway started a new day, just as it has more than 36,000 times since Oct. 27, 1904. A few minutes after
title: A Day in the Subway, as It Rolls Up a Century

title: HAVENS: LIVING HERE; Stone Houses: Long-Lasting Walls of History and Mortar

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ELECTION 2004; Not on Our Lampposts, Bay Ridge Tells Candidates

title: Harassment Claim Is Filed Against Brooklyn Councilman

body: New York Republicans are well aware that their little-known candidate for the United States Senate has a slim chance of defeating Charles E. Schumer, the popular Democratic incumbent. ''We know it's an uphill fight,'' Gov. George E. Pataki said on Monday during an event in Manhattan for the candidate, Howard Mills, a state assemblyman. But Mr.
title: Political Memo; Schumer's Opponents Are Fighting for 2nd Place

body: THE stray dogs are finding their way back to Athens; the shady characters are coming back, too. Heroin addicts, kept out of view for three weeks, nod out around midnight at Omonia Square, reminding the city of a dire social scourge. Seediness, kept at arm's length for a month, comes a bit too close for comfort now. Athens is getting back to normal.
title: Sports of The Times; New York Is Already Up to Speed for 2012

body: The Bay Ridge Towers, two tall brick co-op buildings at the northern tip of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, offer their residents two vast parking lots with an unusual feature. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; A Homeless Colony, Far From Skid Row

title: NEW YORK 2004; Who Can Claim to Know A City of 8 Million?

title: NEW YORK 2004: REPUBLICAN NEW YORK; A Safe Hill For G.O.P.

title: 2 Charged With Plotting To Bomb Train Station

title: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; Party Spirits

title: PREPARING FOR THE CONVENTION: SNAPSHOTS; Yes, New York Has Republican Clubs, With Members

body: THE Afghan counterman at the Kennedy Fried Chicken on Nostrand Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, radiated a look of despair. Every day I have a headache.'' To
title: Chicken Little

body: An armed man walked into a Jennifer Convertibles store in Bay Ridge yesterday, forced a woman who was in the store into a back area, sexually assaulted her and fled, the police said. Investigators said the woman, whose identity was not disclosed, was taken to a nearby hospital. They said the attack occurred about 1 p.m. after the man entered the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Assaulted In Furniture Store

title: Paid Notice: Deaths DIETRICH, SIEGEL, ANDREA

body: Growing up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, in the 1950's, Tom Fox used to take a ferry from the 69th Street pier in Bay Ridge to Staten Island, heading for a scenic waterfront that was home to his Boy Scout camp and sheep-dotted hillsides. The sheep, of course, are long gone and nearly 40 years ago the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge replaced the ferry as a means
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Embracing an Idea of Yore To Bring Manhattan Closer

Bruno, the leader of the Senate's Republican majority. But in its criticism of several centrist votes by Republicans, the Conservative Party did not stop there. Party
title: Conservative Party Refuses To Endorse Senate Leader

body: A federal judge sentenced a New Jersey man yesterday to the maximum five years in prison for lying to investigators during an investigation of terrorism financing efforts that they said were centered in Brooklyn. Federal prosecutors described the sentence as an important victory because it showed that judges would impose stiff penalties on people
title: Man Gets 5 Years for Lying in Terror Inquiry

body: When James and Naila Bateh bought a slightly run-down white house with an expansive porch on 87th Street in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the appeal was clear. The house sat on a tree-lined block between Narrows Avenue and Colonial Road and had a backyard for their three children. Most important, it was only a block from their old house, in the neighborhood
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE/BENSONHURST; Homeowner Plans Addition, Resulting in Division

body: To find out who lives in specific New York City neighborhoods, call the Census Bureau. To determine which neighborhoods have the most crime, ask the Police Department. title: Gambling on Wall St.; No Sex on Upper East Side; Bookstores' Sales Reveal Something About Their Neighborhoods

body: On a sultry afternoon in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, earlier this month, sweaty people trudged down a sun-baked stretch of 18th Avenue while an electric guitar squealed from a car stereo. On the corner of 67th Street, a white-hatted police officer mopped his brow and ticketed a gray Lexus for a meter violation. It is a common sight in the neighborhood
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST/BAY RIDGE; For Residents, Tickets to Deride

body: Tim McLoughlin, a Brooklyn writer and editor, stopped off at a local bar after a Brooklyn Cyclones game. Along with the beer, the bartender, Thomas Morrissey, thrust his unpublished short story, ''Can't Catch Me,'' into his hands. Mr. McLoughlin loved the piece, about a detective who investigates the murder of a Bay Ridge baker who is found dead
title: Brooklyn Crime Tales Flavored by Neighborhood

body: When a Long Island hospital revealed last week that it might have inadvertently exposed 177 patients to H.I.V. and hepatitis during routine endoscopies, hospital officials said the lapse was an embarrassing aberration. But some scientists, health officials and patients said the problems at the hospital, North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset,
title: Virus Risk at L.I. Hospital Underscores Wider Problem

This Italian cheese shop, owned by the same family since 1925, usually has lines reaching out onto the sidewalk, even after moving from its original location at 206 Grand Street (800 square feet) all the way across the
title: Stop and Smell the Cheese; It's Part of the Tradition

title: Chinese Builder's Death Reveals Anonymous Web of Risky Labor

body: A construction worker was killed and two others injured yesterday at a Queens building site when an eight-foot-high concrete wall suddenly collapsed around them as they were working in an unreinforced trench, the authorities said. The accident, which occurred about noon at 92nd Street and 52nd Avenue in Elmhurst, forced other workers at the site to
title: Construction Accident in Queens Kills Worker and Injures 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths ALENCE, EDWARD J.

body: Hoping to gain a competitive edge in international shipping, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey signed an agreement on Friday with the Army Corps of Engineers to deepen channels around New York Bay to 50 feet to accommodate a new generation of extra-large cargo ships. At the same time, Gov. James E. McGreevey, citing terrorism concerns,
title: To Bolster Competitiveness, Dredging Is Planned in Bay

body: SOME home buyers are rushing into the market because mortgage rates have inched up by a percentage point since March, brokers throughout the New York region say. For precisely the same reason, they say, other buyers -- particularly skittish fledglings -- are cringing from taking the plunge. And at the same time, some sellers who had been holding
title: For Home Sales, Spring Fever

body: To the Editor: Re ''. . . And Wondering if a Bike Lane Has Any Room Left for Bikes'' (May 16), about the profusion of cars on the bike lanes of Bay Ridge: Bay Ridge bikers have it easy. At least there the cars in the bike lane are stopped. Every morning in Prospect Park impatient drivers use the bike lane as a high-speed shortcut around the backup
title: Sonny's Song; Bicyclists' Travails In Brooklyn

author: Susan Dominus, a contributing writer, last wrote for the magazine about old age.
body: It was the evening of Sept. 10, 2002, when John Zazulka, a New York City firefighter, sat down with his wife, Susan, in their Staten Island home and told her that their marriage of 19 years was over. At least that's how Susan remembers it, the eve of the one-year anniversary of 9/11, the last night of the worst year of their lives. John, on the
title: One Very Tangled Post- 9/11 Affair

body: The job paid $90 a day with no benefits. It required heavy lifting while balancing on flimsy platforms three stories high, exposed to the elements but not to the knowledge that the work flouted safety rules and construction blueprints. Angel Segovia, 37, took the job, and for him there were even more hardships. Besides having to rise at 4:30 a.m.
title: Laborer's Death Prompts Homicide Investigation

body: A laborer was killed and two others were seriously injured yesterday when a balcony roof that was being illegally built at a new luxury condominium building in Brooklyn gave way, sending the workers tumbling three stories in a deluge of bricks and flowing concrete, the authorities said. The primary contractor on the job, Big Apple Development and
title: Laborer Dies and 2 Are Hurt as Illegal Balcony Roof Falls

body: They sat at the edge of the slow-moving, brackish waters of the Kill Van Kull, two underappreciated freighters that stand as bookends to New York's glorious port history. The Occidental, a 211-foot, three-masted ship that first sailed in 1874, once carried grain to California, railroad tracks to Alaska and coal to Europe and survived a host of
title: In Aging Port, a Glimpse Of the Old New York; Waterfront Tours Bring Forgotten Places to Life

body: People wept and people seethed and people ruminated and people quibbled. This happened uptown and downtown and in Brooklyn and in Queens, at home and at work and on the street. People did what they normally did on a Tuesday in May, or at least most of them did, but they also did this. As the Sept. 11 commission came to town yesterday with its deep
title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: REACTION; A Day of Pain, Detachment And Everything in Between

body: What happened one balmy evening last week on Shore Road in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was typical. First, a man double-parked his S.U.V. in the bike lane and got out to gaze at the water. Soon, a station wagon pulled up and idled behind him. Then a cyclist pedaled by, but had to swerve into the middle of the road to pass the two vehicles, causing a line
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; ...And Wondering if a Bike Lane Has Any Room Left for Bikes

body: There are many types of New York City championships, but how many are held in a sewage treatment plant? The Operators Challenge is. Held annually to determine the city's highest-performing sewage treatment workers, the challenge this year included workers from 8 of the city's 14 wastewater treatment plants. It was won last week by the Jamaica
title: In Olympics Of Sludge, Dirty Work Brings Gold

body: THERE are the Do It Yourself-ers in renovation stories, and then there are the I Did It My Way-ers. Vincent Sgarlato has kind of single-handedly created the second category. Last year, Mr. Sgarlato opened the Summit, a lounge and restaurant at 308 East 49th Street. He worked with an architect, Glen Coben, and the design brief was brief. Sinatra.
title: A Little Sands, A Lot of Sinatra

body: The sight was particularly galling, considering his age. A tiny rider on a red bicycle sliced through a group of adults in Riverside Park. He looked to be no older than 6. The adults, standing on the park's promenade at 103rd Street in Manhattan on a recent Saturday morning, were holding bicycles at the start of a lesson on how to ride. The boy,
title: Much to Learn, and With Twice as Far to Fall

author: Andy Newman is a reporter in the Brooklyn Bureau of The New York Times
body: What I love about Brooklyn is that it's impossible to get a handle on. It lacks anything approaching a center of gravity. Picture the combined populations of Atlanta, Boston, Miami, Cleveland and Seattle crammed into a space smaller than Cincinnati but with a downtown only as impressive as, say, that of Hartford, Conn., and you start to get the
title: OUR CORRESPONENT IN BROOKLYN; A Rare And Stirring Mixture

body: THE beliefs they espouse may be eternal, but the grip that churches and synagogues have on their property can be transitory. With shrinking memberships and demographic shifts as ethnic groups move out of neighborhoods and others move in, houses of worship can be filled to capacity and financially comfortable in one decade and struggling for
title: Sacred Space But Earthly Challenges

body: John Joseph Ryan, formerly a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn and a judge in the criminal and claims courts, died on April 16 at a nursing home in Hinsdale, Ill. He was 92 and formerly a resident of Brooklyn as well as Breezy Point, N.Y., and Westfield, N.J. His death was announced by the Dooley Funeral Service in Westfield. Starting in 1947,
title: John Joseph Ryan, 92, Assemblyman and Judge

body: Robert D. Jones looked straight ahead as if it were just another morning on just another ship, as if that bridge up ahead were just another bridge. But the bridge was one of the world's longest suspension spans, and a few miles beyond was one of the world's most famous statues, and a few miles beyond that a narrow pier where a brass band would be
title: A Queen Arrives, and Even in Jaded New York, Jaws Drop

body: A 65-year-old reputed mob figure described by a law enforcement official as ''erudite and sophisticated'' fatally stabbed his brother-in-law yesterday on the street in front of a Brooklyn restaurant of which the victim was a co-owner, the police said. The suspect, Andrew Gargiulo, who law enforcement officials said ran such a successful bookmaking
title: Mob Figure Accused of Killing Relative

body: A Brooklyn man who was left alone last week with his girlfriend's cat, Darwin, became so enraged at the animal that he beat him to death with his fists, the authorities said last night. Now he is charged with the state's most severe animal abuse charge and, if convicted, could face jail time, they said. The charge against the man, James Whalen, a
title: Brooklyn Man Faces Felony Charge After Arrest in Killing of Cat

body: WALK into Tanoreen, a bright little Middle Eastern storefront in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and it is easy to see who is in charge. Authority and passion emanate from Rawia Bishara like the enticing aromas that waft from the open kitchen. Whether overseeing her cooks or striding through the dining room to greet a familiar face, Ms. Bishara, a tall woman
title: $25 AND UNDER; An Uncompromising Position on the Middle East

body: VINCENT SCOTTO and his sister, Donna Scotto, sat in Gonzo, their Greenwich Village trattoria, eating Chinese takeout and arguing about their grandmother's savory Easter pie -- pizza rustica. Mr. Scotto, the chef, likes to serve it with tomato sauce. ''The tomato sauce pairs well with all the meat,'' he insisted. ''I just like it plain,'' rejoined
title: TEMPTATION; Easter Pizza Is What You Make of It

author: Kenneth T. Jackson, editor of The Encyclopedia of New York City, is Jacques Barzun Professor of History and the Social Sciences at Columbia University.
body: THEY are the events that gave birth to modern New York. In 1898, the five boroughs united in one enormous city of more than 300 square miles and upward of 3.4 million people. Two years later, to serve the huge new city, New York's fledgling Rapid Transit Commission contracted with the financier August Belmont to build, equip and operate the first
title: 1904-2004; If the Subway Had Never Been

author: Lyle Rexer is the author of ''How to Look at Outsider Art,'' to be published next year by Harry N. Abrams.
body: FOR a photographer, the choice of a subject can be as fateful as it is fortuitous. It's often an instantaneous decision, a response to what Henri Cartier-Bresson famously called ''the decisive moment,'' and yet its ramifications can last a lifetime. In 1986, the photographer Andrea Modica was driving through rural Treadwell, New York, when she saw
title: ART; The Shortest of Lifetime Collaborations

body: IN the cosmology of New York City restaurants, there is no dessert more universal than the cheesecake. There are cheesecake variations playing in Manhattan dining rooms both upscale and down: at Gramercy Tavern, at Big Nick's, at ChikaLicious, at David Burke & Donatella. There is a strawberry-covered cheesecake on a pedestal at the Greek coffee
title: In Cheesecake City, a Quest for the Best

body: An aging rail line in Queens became a media sensation last week, even drawing a visit from Mayor Micheal R. Bloomberg, after an accident involving a runaway locomotive drew reporters and television crews to a place filled with long rows of boxcars. But for the absence of cornfields, it could have been a Midwestern freight yard, rather than a
title: City's Trainmen Keep an Iron Age Alive

body: A Bard College student who disappeared Feb. 20 after boarding a Manhattan-bound Metro-North train in Poughkeepsie turned herself in early yesterday at a Long Island police station. The student, Melissa Kennedy, 21, left, appeared, apparently unharmed, at the Southampton Town police station at 1 a.m., after disappearing more than two weeks ago on a
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Southampton: Missing Student Returns

body: His prized possession is a 1947 Gibson acoustic guitar, autographed by his heroes, the country star Merle Haggard and the bluegrass legend Doc Watson. He is rarely spotted without his weather-beaten cowboy hat and rugged boots. He has been known to praise whiskey and tall glasses of beer. Make no mistake: Jack Grace is an old-fashioned country
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- CITYPEOPLE; A Honky-Tonk Man Whose Turf Is the Hip-Hop City

body: Helped by about 20 volunteers, the parents of a Bard College student who disappeared last month while taking a commuter train to New York returned on Saturday to the station she departed from to hand out fliers and announce a $10,000 reward for information leading to her whereabouts. ''We hope that people will come up, be motivated by the reward,
title: Parents Seek Help in Finding Daughter, 21

body: It's been only two weeks since the closing of L'Amour, a live-music club in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, but the heavy metal world is already reeling. A Swedish band called Hypocrisy had to alter its tour plans; a Bay Ridge group is unhappily contemplating gigs in Poughkeepsie. Several metalheads, rarely known to be effusive, have described themselves as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK NIGHT LIFE; At Least the Fans Will Keep Their Hearing

body: To the Editor: I enjoyed "In the Name of Norton" (F.Y.I., Feb. 8) and letters to the editor (Feb. 15), on the subject of naming something in honor of Art Carney, who played the sewer worker Ed Norton on ''The Honeymooners.'' In 1989 at my urging, Howard Golden, then the Brooklyn borough president, proposed that the Gowanus Canal Pumping Station be
title: Surviving The Punk Life; A Watery Tribute To Ed Norton

body: Nine months later, never on Sunday has become sometimes on Sunday. Michael Inabinet set up the sidewalk sign with the smiling, yawning grapes on it outside Pet Wines on the Upper East Side just before noon last Sunday and awaited the stampede of the thirsty masses. ''We usually get a run on Champagne for mimosas,'' he said. A few minutes later in
title: For Liquor Store Owners, a Profitable Sunday Swap

body: But for a chance decision, a newborn baby named Moses lies in the care of Harlem Hospital Center instead of in a darkened storage closet. But for a well-timed cry, a different newborn escaped going out with the trash on the cold stoop of an apartment building in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. But for guidance from calls to an anonymous safe haven service,
title: 3 Abandoned Newborns Saved In a Day of Luck and Kindness

author: Maura Egan is the style director of Details magazine.
body: Tourists, with their sensible sneakers and no-neck children, lining up like lemmings to get a glimpse of Matt and Katie at the Rockefeller Center fishbowl, have turned the better part of Manhattan's Fifth Avenue into the Mall of America. With the avenue's S.U.V.-choked traffic and an Ann Taylor and a Gap on every corner, you might as well
title: In The Trenches

body: When the first train rumbles across the Manhattan Bridge on Sunday morning, the confusion will begin for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers adjusting to the most significant redrawing of the subway map in decades. The changes come with the nearly two-decade rehabilitation of the bridge finally coming to an end, and four subway tracks, instead of
title: A Subway Map Remade, in Hopes of Matching Routes and Riders

body: A New Jersey gas station owner was convicted yesterday of making false statements to federal agents when he denied helping a Yemeni cleric who prosecutors said made a trip to Brooklyn in 1999 to raise money for international terrorism. The verdict from a jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn came in a case that exposed many details of a
title: Man Guilty Of Lying To the F.B.I. In Sheik Case

body: An autopsy on the decomposed body of a man who was found in a duffel bag in the trunk of a car in Bay Ridge late Sunday determined that he had died from a single gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said yesterday. The body was found just before 11 p.m. Sunday in the trunk of a maroon Mazda parked in front of 402 100th Street, the police
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Found In Duffel Bag Was Shot In Head

body: INCREASING numbers of homeowners in neighborhoods across the city are deciding that the grass is greener on their own side of the fence, choosing to sink significant amounts of money into alterations or expansions rather than move on to grander addresses or the suburbs. There is, of course, nothing new about remodeling: the caveman probably redid
title: Moving Up Without Moving On

body: Contrary to popular belief, Brooklyn did not die when a rich man named Walter O'Malley took away the Dodgers after the 1957 baseball season. Brooklyn is still there. From the edge of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, gazing east, you can see a silhouette of towers, bridges, piers and steeples that would take your breath away if they suddenly
title: Sports of The Times; A New Bounce in Brooklyn's Step

body: UNTIL now, basketball in Brooklyn mostly meant schoolyard courts or the high school gyms where teenagers learned to shoot and pass, to dunk and defend. You could dream about playing for the Knicks at the Garden, but if you had big-time talent, you had to go away to a college out there in the sticks where you knew you would feel like a stranger.
title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Crosses Bridge Back Into the Big Time

body: AMONG the many great lies that keep the world spinning -- ''The check is in the mail,'' ''This won't hurt a bit,'' ''Sure, I'll respect you in the morning'' -- is the one about New Yorkers' being able to put up with anything. That loving myth has comforted the people of this city for generations. But there is one thing that many of them absolutely
title: NYC; Hey Cabby, The Fare Rise Is in the Mail

body: FLICKERING before Amanda M. Burden, the city planning commissioner, was a vision of New York City of the future. A computer animation showed the view from a car driving toward the Greenpoint waterfront in Brooklyn. The industrial buildings were gone, replaced by a stately procession of five- and six-story brick and stone apartment buildings,
title: Remaking, or Preserving, the City's Face

body: If you were robust enough to stare down the blustery winds and bone-chilling temperatures last week and go for a midwinter stroll along the Brooklyn waterfront, you probably noticed, every 20 minutes or so, a cab-yellow boat sturdily bobbing through the harbor. Like the United States Postal Service, New York Water Taxi, which runs the boats, takes
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK WATERWAYS; You Think You're Cold? Try Braving the Water Taxi

body: The revival of Brooklyn has been painfully slow, an effort eked out neighborhood by neighborhood, with chic new restaurants in Fort Greene, artists' lofts in Williamsburg, new businesses in industrial Red Hook and the transformation of derelict factory buildings into million-dollar condominiums in an area with the unlikely name of Dumbo. But the
title: Yo, Dodgers? No Way! Brooklyn Is Betting on the Nets for Revival

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg promoted his accomplishments yesterday and provided a peek into his agenda for the coming year. His plans include a campaign against gun crimes, a tax rebate for homeowners and an end to the practice of social promotion for third graders in the public schools. He spoke at length about overdevelopment on Staten Island and
title: Mayor Offers Coming Attractions on Safety, Taxes and Schools

body: ROSEMARY M. BAKKER'S career as an interior designer took an abrupt turn when her mother fell 13 years ago and broke her hip. The house where her mother lived in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was transformed by the injury into an obstacle course. ''When I saw the house through my mother's eyes, I began to see interior design differently,'' Ms. Bakker said.
title: PUBLIC LIVES; From Coordinating Colors to Helping the Infirm
